block.p: LEAD: The Economy
LEAD: The Economy
The Economy

The Consumer Price Index rose 0.4 percent in November, as food and shelter grew more costly while energy prices edged down, in an increase that was higher than expected. [ Page D1. ] Housing starts dropped by 4.7 percent last month. [ D8. ]
The unusual design of a destructive computer program may have undermined an elaborate extortion attempt. [ D8. ] International

President Bush waived a Congressional ban on loans to companies that do business with China. [ A1. ] Commerce Secretary Mosbacher said a deal to help lay a fiber-optic communications cable across the Soviet Union could proceed, provided the latest technology is not used. [ D1. ]
The European Community and six Western European nations agreed, as expected, to intensify negotiations about setting up a common economic space with minimal trade barriers. [ D16. ]
Bowing to public pressure, the Canadian Government will lower the rate on its proposed value-added tax to 7 percent. [ A6. ] Companies
Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts is prepared to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for Hillsborough Holdings, the company it formed to acquire Jim Walter last year for $2.4 billion. [ D1. ]
American Airlines agreed to acquire Eastern's Central and South American routes. [ D5. ]

Bankers Trust said fourth-quarter earnings would be cut by $90 million after taxes, because of losses on two large loans. [ D2. ] Bank problems with real estate loans are growing, the Comptroller of the Currency said. [ D2. ]
TLC Beatrice abandoned a plan to sell a 35 percent stake to the public, citing what it called unfavorable market conditions. [ D5. ]
A.T.& T. will reduce rates by 1.3 to 2 percent on interstate and international long-distance services. [ D5. ]
Xerox's $150 million copyright suit against Apple is an important skirmish in a battle to determine whether desktop computers should have a standard ''dashboard.'' News Analysis. [ D7. ]
I.B.M. introduced a personal computer based on Intel's powerful i486 micoprocessor. [ D8. ]
Reader's Digest is going public, in a move that will give its shareholders greater liquidity. [ D19. ] Markets
Stock prices declined broadly, and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 1.92 points, to close at 2,695.61. [ D10. ]
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading. [ D16. ] Yields were mostly mixed on C.D.'s and money market accounts for the week ended yesterday. [ D22. ]

The contract for January delivery of crude oil expired in volatile trading. Prices set contract highs before closing with a sharp decline. [ D17. ] The dollar finished slightly higher. [ D17. ] Technology
The race to develop stronger, lighter materials that will make aircraft more sturdy and more fuel-efficient is intensifying. [ D6. ]
A platform for the North Sea will be built to take account of higher waters that might result from the greenhouse effect. [ D6. ] Today's Columns
Times have changed at The New Yorker, which has lent its name to a luxury-car road rally and mailed advertising promotions to readers. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D1. ]
Evidence that the house may not be worth what it cost may lead to a pullback by investors. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D1. ]
Should anyone care if a company's stockholders are Japanese rather than American? Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ]
